text:
In this video, you’ll see how to manage 
data grants in AWS Data Exchange.

With this solution, users can create
data grants to share data with other

AWS accounts, and receivers can accept 
data grants to get read-only access to data.

As a data sender, you can use 
data grants to share data sets

with other AWS accounts without the need 
to register as an AWS Marketplace seller.
To get started, let's create a data set.
We’ll create a files-based data set.
Next, we’ll provide a name and description.

Let’s create the data set and 
continue to the next step.

Here, we can create revisions 
for the data set if needed.
In this case, we’ll skip this step.
Next, we’ll upload our sample data.
The upload is now complete.

Let’s review the details 
and finalize the data set.

Now we’ll create a data 
grant to share the data set.

The data grant needs to be created in the same 
AWS Region that the data set was created in.

Any data sets that are available to 
share in the Region we’re in appear here.
We’ll choose the data set we just created.

Next, we’ll provide a name and 
description for the data grant.

Next, we’ll provide the AWS 
account ID of the recipient account
we want to share the data with.

We’ll also specify an end date 
for the recipient’s data access.

The end date can be left blank if 
the grant will exist in perpetuity.

With both options, as the data grant 
creator, you are able to delete it at any time.

Now let’s review the information, and 
then create and send the data grant.

It can take up to 10 minutes for the 
data grant to be created and sent.

For demonstration purposes, let’s skip 
ahead to when the data grant has been sent.

We’re now logged into the data 
grant recipient’s account.

In AWS Data Exchange, let’s navigate 
to the Received data grants page.

Here, we can see any pending 
data grants, including their status,
expiration date, and start date.
Let’s open the grant created earlier.

The overview includes a
description of the grant,

and we can see the entitled 
data set that is included.
Let’s accept this data grant.
While the request is being processed,

we can return to the Received data 
grants page to monitor its status.

Once the data grant request 
has finished processing,

it will appear under Accepted 
and expired data grants.
Let’s open the data grant.

The entitled data set can be 
opened from the data grant itself,
or from the Entitled data page.

We can also export the data 
to Amazon S3 if needed.

You’ve just seen how to manage 
data grants in AWS Data Exchange.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
